uk.co.saiman.data

Interface ContinuousFunction<UD extends javax.measure.Quantity<UD>,UR extends javax.measure.Quantity<UR>>

  • Type Parameters:
    UD - the type of the units of measurement of values in the domain
    UR - the type of the units of measurement of values in the range
    All Superinterfaces:
    uk.co.strangeskies.utilities.Copyable<ContinuousFunction<UD,UR>>, uk.co.strangeskies.mathematics.expression.Expression<ContinuousFunction<UD,UR>>, uk.co.strangeskies.utilities.Observable<uk.co.strangeskies.mathematics.expression.Expression<? extends ContinuousFunction<UD,UR>>>, uk.co.strangeskies.utilities.Self<ContinuousFunction<UD,UR>>, uk.co.strangeskies.mathematics.expression.SelfExpression<ContinuousFunction<UD,UR>>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    ContinuousFunctionDecorator<UD,UR>, SampledContinuousFunction<UD,UR>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AccumulatingContinuousFunction, ArraySampledContinuousFunction, ContinuousFunctionExpression, LockingSampledContinuousFunction, PeakShapeImpulseConvolutionFunction, SparseSampledContinuousFunction

    public interface ContinuousFunction<UD extends javax.measure.Quantity<UD>,UR extends javax.measure.Quantity<UR>>
extends uk.co.strangeskies.mathematics.expression.SelfExpression<ContinuousFunction<UD,UR>>
    A set of domain values (X) mapped via some continuous function to a corresponding value in the range (Y). The domain is defined by a single inclusive interval, and the function is defined for all values in the domain.

    ContinuousFunctions may be mutable, depending on implementation, but in this case they should notify listeners by way of the API provided through SelfExpression.

    TODO: Difficult to genericise over data type with acceptable performance until Project Valhalla, for now will just use double.

      • resample

        SampledContinuousFunction<UD,UR> resample(SampledDomain<UD> resolvableSampleDomain)
        Sometimes it is useful to linearize a continuous function in order to perform complex processing, or for display purposes. This method provides a linear view of any continuous function. Implementations may remove features which are unresolvable at the given resolution.

        Note that the parameter only represents the resolvable domain and the contained samples may not be exactly represented in the domain of the output. For example an implementation may retain some sub-resolution features to indicate maxima and minima within a resolvable interval, such that thin peaks and troughs don't disappear from visual representation at low resolution.

        Parameters:
        resolvableSampleDomain - a representation of the resolvable sample domain
        Returns:
        a new sampled, linear continuous function roughly equal to the receiver to the requested resolution
